title: Introduction to Python Programming
author: AI Book Creator
description: A comprehensive guide to learning Python programming from basics to advanced concepts.
preface: Welcome to this comprehensive guide on Python programming. This book is designed to take you from a complete beginner to a confident Python developer. We'll cover fundamental concepts, practical examples, and best practices that will help you write clean, efficient code.

chapters.title: Getting Started with Python
chapters.introduction: Python is one of the most popular programming languages today. In this chapter, we'll introduce you to Python and set up your development environment.
chapters.summary: You've learned what Python is, why it's popular, and how to set up your development environment. You're now ready to start writing Python code!

sections.title: What is Python?
sections.content: Python is a high-level, interpreted programming language known for its simplicity and readability. Created by Guido van Rossum in 1991, Python emphasizes code readability with its use of significant whitespace. Python supports multiple programming paradigms including procedural, object-oriented, and functional programming.

code_examples.code:
# Your first Python program
print("Hello, World!")

# Python is known for its simple syntax
name = "Alice"
print(f"Hello, {name}!")
code_examples.explanation: This simple example demonstrates Python's clean syntax. The print() function displays output, and f-strings provide an elegant way to format strings.

sections.title: Installing Python
sections.content: To start programming in Python, you need to install it on your computer. Visit python.org to download the latest version. Python is available for Windows, macOS, and Linux. During installation, make sure to check the option to add Python to your system PATH.

code_examples.code:
# Verify Python installation
# Run this in your terminal or command prompt
python --version

# Alternative command
python3 --version
code_examples.explanation: These commands verify that Python is correctly installed and show the installed version.

sections.title: Your First Python Program
sections.content: Let's write your first Python program. Create a new file called hello.py and add some code. Python files use the .py extension. You can run your program from the command line using 'python hello.py'.

code_examples.code:
# hello.py
# This is a comment - Python ignores everything after #

print("Welcome to Python programming!")
print("Let's learn together.")

# Variables store data
age = 25
print(f"I am {age} years old.")
code_examples.explanation: This program demonstrates comments, the print function, variables, and string formatting.

exercises.question: Create a Python program that prints your name and favorite programming language.
exercises.answer:
name = "Your Name"
language = "Python"
print(f"My name is {name} and I love {language}!")
hints: Use the print() function to display output
Store your name in a variable
Use an f-string to combine text and variables

chapters.title: Python Basics: Variables and Data Types
chapters.introduction: Understanding variables and data types is fundamental to programming. In this chapter, you'll learn how Python handles different types of data and how to work with them effectively.
chapters.summary: You now understand Python's basic data types including integers, floats, strings, and booleans. You can create variables and perform operations on different data types.

sections.title: Variables and Assignment
sections.content: Variables are containers for storing data values. In Python, you don't need to declare a variable's type - Python figures it out automatically. This is called dynamic typing. Variable names should be descriptive and follow Python naming conventions.

code_examples.code:
# Variable assignment
name = "Alice"          # String
age = 30               # Integer
height = 5.6           # Float
is_student = True      # Boolean

# Multiple assignment
x, y, z = 1, 2, 3

# Same value to multiple variables
a = b = c = 0
code_examples.explanation: Python makes variable assignment simple and flexible. You can assign multiple variables in one line or give the same value to multiple variables.

sections.title: Numeric Data Types
sections.content: Python has three numeric types: int (integers), float (decimal numbers), and complex (complex numbers). You can perform mathematical operations on numeric types and convert between them.

code_examples.code:
# Integer operations
x = 10
y = 3

print(x + y)    # Addition: 13
print(x - y)    # Subtraction: 7
print(x * y)    # Multiplication: 30
print(x / y)    # Division: 3.333...
print(x // y)   # Floor division: 3
print(x % y)    # Modulus: 1
print(x ** y)   # Exponentiation: 1000
code_examples.explanation: Python supports all standard mathematical operations. Note the difference between / (regular division) and // (floor division).

exercises.question: Write a program that calculates the area of a circle given its radius. Use π = 3.14159.
exercises.answer:
radius = 5
pi = 3.14159
area = pi * radius ** 2
print(f"The area is {area}")

sections.title: Strings and String Operations
sections.content: Strings are sequences of characters enclosed in quotes. Python treats single and double quotes the same. Strings are immutable, meaning once created, they cannot be changed. However, you can create new strings based on existing ones.

code_examples.code:
# String operations
greeting = "Hello"
name = "World"

# Concatenation
message = greeting + ", " + name + "!"
print(message)  # Hello, World!

# String methods
text = "python programming"
print(text.upper())        # PYTHON PROGRAMMING
print(text.capitalize())   # Python programming
print(text.title())        # Python Programming
print(len(text))          # 18

# String slicing
word = "Python"
print(word[0])      # P
print(word[0:3])    # Pyt
print(word[-1])     # n
code_examples.explanation: Strings in Python are versatile. You can concatenate them, apply methods to transform them, and slice them to extract parts.
